A while back - just for fun - I took a pretty bad pun on Seinfeld's
"Festiv=
us" a bit too far and blogged about "Testivus - Unit testing
for the rest o=
f us":

http://www.artima.com/weblogs/viewpost.jsp?thread=3D194506

Based o=
n the number of replies and positive emails I received from
that blog, I re=
alized that the idea of Testivus (an approach to
unit/developer testing les=
s focused on testing dogma and more on
testing karma) had struck a nerve an=
d decided to take the idea of
Testivus even further and wrote "The Way of T=
estivus".

Since the inspiration for some of the ideas presented in TWOT ca=
me
from this and a couple of other groups, I thought I'd share it with
you.=
  You might even recognize some of the text and arguments as
*near* plagiar=
ism of some of the posts that have been made here.

In one case, in a tenet=
 about what constitutes a unit test, I plucked
(no pun intended) a few sent=
ences from Michael Feathers because I
could not possibly improve on them, b=
ut I gave him credit (albeit a
bit disguised).

You can find a fun, exotic,=
 and "antiqued" looking PDF copy of "The
Way of Testivus" - complete with a=
 background story on its mysterious
origins - at the following link:

http:=
//www.agitar.com/downloads/TheWayOfTestivus.pdf

You can also read the basi=
c tenets of Testivus on Wikpedia, but it's
not as cool looking or easy to r=
ead as the PDF.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Testivus

What do you think? =
 What other tenets should we add to Testivus?  Feel
free to suggest some.

=
Alberto
